item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
Hello readers!
I am an HMIS Data Analyst for one large CoC and one small CoC, and part of a really great HIMS team. I focus on reporting and since we use ServicePoint, I primarily use a deprecated version of SAP Business Objects until we get Qlik to a usable state. I have also been using Tableau lately so I may be including posts about that as well. But most of the content here is related to reports I built using Business Objects.
The target audience for this blog is pretty tiny, but I love love love writing about new things I learn and sharing my work with others who are also using ServicePoint to turn out solid reports to help their CoCs achieve their goals. Leave comments if you find something helpful or if you have ideas that may help me/others.
-Genelle Denzin

item.title: Collaborate 2013
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
My workmates and I attended the latest Bowman conference in Scottsdale Arizona. The first two days consisted of Advanced ART training, and the rest of the week was dedicated to conference sessions. Since there were HUD reps presenting, it was difficult to really choose other sessions because it's always good to hear the latest from those who are on the inside. <!--more--> Some takeaways from the conference included learning that recording services in HMIS is actually not mandatory (at least for HUD programs) and the only indication we have of entering them in the future is based on a DRAFT version of the new data standards. Apparently this round of Data Standards went out for comment and unlike the other releases (in 2004 and 2010), the final 2013 Data Standards will be somewhat different from the Draft ones. The comments received back on the Draft 2013 Data Standards were in the thousands.
The ART-related takeaways were mostly about associated dimensions, future-proofing your reporting, and recidivism ideas. I will write more about these things in other blog posts!
Most of all, the funnest part of the conference was spending time with the people there. My workmates are always good to be around, and the Bowman crowd happens to be a really lively and fun group of people. It's really good to meet the people you go to for help on a regular basis. Also we met many others who are managing HMIS implementations around the nation and got to hear the various ways they are dealing with the same (and different) issues that we are in the Ohio Balance of State.
We mostly came away from the conference feeling like we were mostly going in the right direction, but that a few priorities could be rearranged to account for final regulations being in draft status.

item.title: Why I Snark on Input Controls
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
At the conference last week, our Advanced ART training class spent about an hour on learning how to set up Input Controls on custom reports. I have many thoughts about Input Controls, which I thought I was being subtle about expressing, but apparently my distaste for them got out via my notes I accidentally left behind after class, so now that that cat's out of the bag, I'll use this space to lay out exactly all my objections to the idea of adding Input Controls to custom reports. Input controls in ART are meant to allow end users to run a report, then adjust which data is showing based on their selections. Speaking of end users, our end users are typically case managers at agencies that serve many individuals and families and have a lot of important work to do. It's work I couldn't do. They are not always technically agile, and the ones who are have very little time. I feel pretty strongly that it is our job as HMIS administrators to make their lives easier. Here's what Input Controls look like to the end user (once they find the tiny obscure button to view the controls!): If a user selected "Missing" from the Race dropdown, then all the records that had missing Race data would show in the report. Seems like an ok thing, couldn't hurt, right? Here are the main problems I have with this: 1. The dropdowns work as multiple AND statements strung together, so that if in each dropdown, the user were to select "Missing", then it would only show the records with "Missing" data in ALL the objects. The casual user will not understand this nuance. Even if trained. 2. End users generally like to print out their work so they don't need to flip from tab to tab looking for Client IDs and so they can indicate on paper which ones they have completed. Further, these reports will time out if left untouched for ten to fifteen minutes. So because of this, users are likely to want to print what they need so they can work on it throughout the work day as they have spare moments. Input controls force users to print multiple pages to show each iteration of the filters they are using to get the various data sets. If an end user wanted to print all the missing data for each data element here, they would potentially (depending on how bad the data was) be looking at saving 10 separate files and printing at least 10 separate pages just to get a list of Client IDs with any missing data. And a client might show up on multiple pages, so if the end user was trying to work from those printed pages, they would be pulling up the same client multiple times. 3. As I stated before, case managers are busy and generally not interested in learning Boolean logic in order to get their data into compliance. Many of the reports HMIS users have to run have upwards of 10 prompts they have to fill out just to run the report. And the prompts have to be filled out just so or the report will be way off. We spend hours per week helping people, reminding, sending the screen shot document, all so that the users can get those prompts filled in correctly. I am of the mind that when an end user goes through all this simply to get a report, they should have the gold once they get those prompts sorted out. However, if you design a report to show more than the user needs to see, then they actually have to go and find the Input Controls tab, and do more work and more concentrating in order to finally get the data they are looking for. This would also create more help desk tickets, or worse, users getting the wrong data and thinking it's correct. 4. The final problem with it is that there are many ways of querying and organizing data so that end users can run a report and have exactly what they need out of it, most the time all on one printable page. So if there are ways around this, then why include this feature? Why design a report that is basically a data dump and leave it to the users to find what they are looking for? Some of the elements of ART report design that can help with avoiding Input Controls are:
  • Breaking (aka Grouping)
  • Sections
  • Good use of prompts (optional and otherwise)
  • Alerters
Here's an example of a way of using report design to get around the need for input controls: While I generally try to avoid using Input Controls in my reporting, I have to admit I have found them useful myself every once in awhile, when I'm looking for something in a report that's already been created. Also, I do understand why Bowman, for instance, might create a report with Input Controls, since they are writing their reports for such a wide audience who may be using these larger data dump type reports for many various things. However, for our single implementation, we try to make the reports our users run as simple, direct, and straightforward as possible.

item.title: The Rapid Rehousing Data Pull (for Abt)
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: Has your HMIS implementation had to submit data to Abt for your Rapid Rehousing pilot project? Are you still in the middle of trying to get the data out so you can get around to your AHAR and other things? I just submitted ours on Friday, and wanted to blog about it since others might be in the middle of theirs still, or some may want to compare notes as to how they designed the report in ART. Please recognize that this isn't necessarily the *best* or *right* way to do it, it's just the way *I* did it. Prior to doing any work in ART, I had to consult with the provider on Client IDs. I looked up all the names, and sent any questions via email, only referring to the Client IDs. I called her when it was necessary to use names with her. At the end of that, I had modified the finder file so that it had three new columns: Client ID, Secondary Client ID (for duplicates), and Household ID (to help with identifying family members). The other preliminary work I did was going through the spreadsheet and Word documents and all the (often contradictory) instructions Abt sent. I sent an email with about 10 questions and got answers back to all of them. Then I set out to write out what data elements were needed and for whom they needed to be pulled in. I marked up that sheet with S's for "Signer", F's for "Family" and O's for "Other". So for each data element I knew who should have it and who shouldn't. Basically the way I did it was I created 6 different queries: Clients: based on the Entry Exit Universe, this pulls alllll the data elements Abt is asking for. Filtering out inactive clients and EEs, and also created an or clause that specifies the relevant providers and a few clients that had signed the agreement and were in HMIS but they didn't actually have an EE in the Rapid Rehousing providers. There were a couple others who had to be added in because they were duplicate Client IDs of a signer. The Client ID with an EE for the RRH provider would show up just fine, but I had to make it so the other one showed as well. So I hard coded those to be included. Providers: based on the Resource Point Universe, pulls in the basic elements indicated in the spreadsheet that Abt sent out for the providers.csv part. This way I wouldn't need to include these things in each of the other pages, as it indicated. No filters at all. Income: based on the Entry Exit Universe. Filters out inactive RecordSet IDs and clients, also looks to the Clients query to get EE IDs. NonCash: based on the Entry Exit Universe. Filters out inactive RecordSet IDs and clients, also looks to the Clients query to get EE IDs. Disabilities: based on the Entry Exit Universe. Filters out inactive RecordSet IDs and clients, also looks to the Clients query to get EE IDs. Clients All Stays: also based on the Entry Exit Universe, this query was basically the same as the Clients one except the parameters were all in a subquery on Client ID. All the same large group of data elements were also included here. When you run the report, because I hard coded the providers and client IDs that were exceptions to the rule, there are really no prompts. The variables I created were pretty simple, but tedious to put together. Here are the main ones: Signers: ClientID where InList (all the client IDs that match up to the modified finder file separated by semicolons) Family: Client ID where HH ID InList (all the Household IDs from the modified finder file) The reports I created as tabs are: Signers: Only returns the Client IDs of signers. The report actually pulls in the extras indicated in the query, but I use a filter to take them out since all we want on this report is the data they're asking for in reference to the Signers. I would have left them out of the query, but they needed to be in there for other reports. Providers: Returns the data elements indicated in the spreadsheet Abt sent out. Had to filter for only the RRH providers on the report end because I needed all the providers to show for some of the other reports. Family Members: Returns Client IDs of Signers and all clients that share a Household ID with them. This report includes Signers because I asked Abt if it should and they said yes. So it includes Heads of Household and family members, but since Abt is asking for different data for family members and Signers, I used an Alerter to null out those data elements they didn't want to see for Signers. I only included the data elements here that they indicated they wanted to see on Family Members. Income: Returns income records for all clients, Signers, Family, and Other. NonCash: Returns Noncash Benefit records for all clients, Signers, Family, and Other. Disabilities: Returns Disability records for Signers and Other. Clients All Stays: based on the Clients All Stays query, this report shows all client IDs served by the RRH providers plus the data Abt was asking for in regards to these clients. There's an extra column on this report called "S=Signers F=Family O=Other" where I have it return an S if the Client ID is included in the Signers variable, an F if it's included in the Family variable, and an O if neither of those things are true. I also included a blank column in the beginning called Family ID so that when I exported it to Excel, I could match up the Client IDs to the Family ID and this way Abt will know which clients are meant to be which Family ID. I felt like this was important because of the duplicates issue and any Signers that (supposedly) weren't served by the RRH provider. When I uploaded this to the repository, the comments I got back were asking me to rearrange the data into three tabs. This is something he was suggesting I do on the Excel end of things. I pushed back because I was under water at the time with rolling out Interims and Followups and other projects, and he said that was ok. However, if you are submitting for the first time, it could be nice to do that for them. What he did point out, however, that I'd forgotten was SERVICES!!!! EEK! So I had to go back in and add a query and tab for Services. Exported to Excel, it wouldn't all fit on one worksheet, so it was actually continued. Tons of data.

item.title: Interims and Follow Ups Implementation
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: Are you using Interims and Followups in your ServicePoint implementation? With the recent change HUD made to the CoC APR, instead of introducing the workaround offered up by Bowman, we decided to jump both feet first and just get Interims and Followups set up and implemented so that our users can have this tool. Last week, we sent out the instructions and the email explaining to the users about the new APR, etc. We also finally finished setting up our providers today. The set up was very easy, though having to touch each of our 400 providers to set it up was pretty unwieldy. Prior to set up, we had to make a few decisions. We edited the picklist called Review so that there were only two choices: Annual Review, and General Review. This picklist had a default list that went like "30 Day Review" and so on. We got rid of the #Day type defaults because 1. that field is not used in any HUD reporting anyway, and 2. how long after an Entry or Exit a Review happened wouldn't be calculated using this field, it would be calculated using the Review Date - the Entry/Exit Date. So we couldn't think of a good reason to keep those and went with the Keep It Simple model. The other decision we had to make was what to collect at Interim and what to collect at Followup. We decided to create two separate assessments since they're really different circumstances, and so that it would be easy to change one without changing the other in the future. Plus, there's no need to collect some of the data during a program stay. Like updating Housing Status, for instance, would be meaningless during a program stay. Many of the questions ask about the client's situation specifically at Entry. These wouldn't work on an Interim assessment either. So it basically came down to Income and Non Cash questions and subassessments on the Interim assessment, and for the Followup assessment, we basically put the Universal Data Elements minus the more static data elements about a client, like DOB, Race, Ethnicity, etc. Our last step in implementing this was adding a column for missing Interims on our modified version of the version 15 CoC APR. We basically keep two versions of every APR: one is the straight-up APR from Bowman as is, and the other has extra tabs in the back with separate blocks of a single column each that details the Client IDs for some calculation up in the front of the report. Many of these come from Question 7, where it calculates missing data. Others come from Question 18a, Disabilities, or Question 8, Households Only Children, Unknown Household Types, etc. You basically just have to copy the formula from whatever calculation you want to display and put it into a field on your back page by itself, and take out the "Count()" piece of the formula. You also usually have to tell it to look at the Client ID instead of the Unique Client ID. The formula I used for finding Missing Interims is: =[Inc Exit].[Entry Exit Client Id] Where ([Inc Adj Interim] In([Inc Exit].[Entry Exit Client Id]) = -2 And [EE Leave or Stay]="S" And [EE LOS]>364) Hope this helps someone out there! :)

item.title: Collaborating in HMIS Land
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
For the past few days, I've been questioning the necessity and purpose of this website. I could not quite place what was wrong, but the main gist of it was that I don't have the best ideas in the world, and many other HMIS's around the US are light years ahead of us in terms of accomplishments, so why put this out there? A lot of the fuel behind the idea of keeping this website comes from watching how the SQL community does it. I attended a SQL Saturday event in Columbus a couple of years ago because I missed my SQL days and kind of thought it could help me somehow even though I don't get to use SQL anymore in my work. <long heaving sobs here> During the conference, I felt like there was really good energy and the presenters were great. There was a Women in Technology contingent full of brilliant happy women willing to listen and talk to you. After the conference, I found several of them on Twitter. They are constantly blogging about their work, sharing with each other, banging out good ideas, SQL questions, etc. The other catalyst was the most recent Bowman conference. I left that feeling like a lot of the value we got from that conference was from the people we met. I really loved hearing how other people who do the same exact work I do think through things, what ideas they have, what hurdles they have and how those differ from ours, what has worked, and what has not. I felt like we shared similar frustrations and had similar goals. If those of us working in HMIS across the country were more connected between conferences, it could be really useful for work, but also to counter that feeling that you're dealing with a unique monster that no one has ever seen before. Thus, this website. I think other HMIS admins will find it somewhat useful, even if just to know sort of what the Ohio Balance of State HMIS is up to, at least from my perspective. Also, where else would I go to express my ART rage? Not to beat an overused term to death, but collaborating with each other across state/county lines can only be a good thing!
"Use what talents you possess: The woods would be silent if no birds sang there except those that sang best." - Henry Van Dyke

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You're right - using the power of the internet to learn more from people you met at a conference who share your type of work - that is a perk we have now that our parents did not have.
Love the blog - just found it today... keep it up! Very informative. T

item.title: Using Match()
item.dc:creator: Genelle

item.title: CoC Performance Measurements Report
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: Our CoC has been working on putting together a document of performance measurements for all the agencies to strive to meet. The first I heard of it was a request for us to please run an Annual Performance Report (APR) on every Transitional Housing (TH) provider in the Balance of State. I'm usually pretty easy going, but to this I said wait just a second... Basically I asked what it was they wanted to know from the APR and set out to try and modify the APR to pull in a column for providers so that we could just run one report and have it show all the things they wanted to see, but for each provider. It didn't work. And Bowman doesn't support janking with the APR universe, so... I started from scratch, just trying to build one measurement at a time, not really believing I would be able to finish it, or get everything we wanted in it. But now it's looking like I will be able to include everything they need! This is turning out to be a big deal because our Balance of State CoC board's Performance and Outcomes Committee has been putting together a Performance Measurement document for months now, and this report is meant to report on all the elements agreed upon by the committee, and then hopefully voted in at the Balance of State CoC board meeting later in the year. While I realize many CoC's have documents like this already, this is a first for our CoC. Anyway, I set the report up to run by program type. It will show all the providers from one program type at a time. So basically you have to run the same report 6 times to get all the providers: Emergency Shelters (ES), Transitional Housing (TH), Permanent Supportive Housing (PSH), Services Only programs (SSO), Safe Havens, and Rapid Rehousing (RRH). They like it that way because when they're looking at and comparing all the numbers, they can look at it with that particular program type code in mind. Here's what it looks like: In this case, I ran the report on Emergency Shelters, so the blurred out Provider column is showing a list of Emergency Shelters, along with their specific numbers. I am using alerters to make anything under the goal be red, and anything above 2% missing data to be red as well. The report includes about 7 different measures, some of them only applicable to certain program types. For each of the 7 measures, I also created a Detail page. Honestly, it started as a staging area for me. I built the measurement page, and in trying to get the formulas to come out right, I would add a tab, pull in all the relevant columns, and just play with them to see how they worked best together. Then I'd leave that in once I had it working, because I figured we would need to see Client IDs and such so we could back up the numbers that were showing on the Performance Measurement tabs. I made them look nice and tried to make them total up nicely to demonstrate what we were looking at. So in all, it's 14 tabs plus the final one that gives the prompts and such. Of course the question came up: if we're going to use this report as a way of scoring applications and funding is tied to it, the agencies are going to mutiny if they don't have a way of pulling this kind of data on themselves, one at a time, with details. So I struggled with that one awhile, trying to think of how we could use these 14 tabs for them, but then they'd see all of everyone's data, and that wouldn't be good. I was also thinking about the fact that the committee wasn't going to necessarily need the detail pages in its report, since they're just comparing the numbers, talking about things from more of a forest level than a leaf level. So one day I made a copy of what I'd done so far with the main report, then went into the queries to change things up a bit. I took out the ability to choose a program type code and replaced it with a provider prompt. I pretty much kept everything else the same. So now when I ran it, I was getting the full report, but for only one provider. This made the performance measurement tabs very short and it made me think I could maybe combine the 14 pages into 7 by moving the detail block onto the performance measurement report. So I did that and liked the results. Next, I started thinking about what I would want to know if it were me trying to be sure my agency was hitting all the performance goals. Basically I'd want to know if there were any measurement goals I wasn't hitting, and if I wasn't, then how far off was I? Next, I'd want to look at all my numbers to see if they matched what I understood about my program. If they didn't, I'd want to look at the client IDs, and any relevant data so I could find any data quality issues or ask questions about how the measure was calculated. I'd also want to know when I'd achieved a measure successfully. It should be easy to see and recognize. So I created formulas that would return different performance measurement goals depending on the program type code of the provider chosen in the prompt. So if I run the report as an Emergency Shelter, it gives me 7 tabs, and at the top of each one, it tells me what the goal is for my program type, what my numbers are, and if I achieved the goal, it says "Achieved" in green. If I didn't achieve the goal, it returns the percentage I'm off by. So if we're looking at Employed at Exit, the goal for Emergency Shelters is 10%. Let's say my percentage is only 6%. Instead of "Achieved", it would say "-4%" in red. Now I know that I'm a little bit off so I can look at my detail and try to figure out if I have any missing data that could be corrected to get my percentage up. Or I may have to think about reviewing the case manager workflow to be sure clients are being connected with employment services, where they exist. Here's what it looks like: I think this design is good because you can see the goal compared to your numbers, and then you can see exactly which client is being counted that isn't within the goal, so you can check for accuracy, or reflect on what happened with that client. It involved some pretty fun formulas that adjust based on which program type the provider you pick is. If I'd picked an Emergency Shelter and looked at this particular tab, it would have said "There is no goal for this measure." and instead of "Achieved", it would have said "N/A". This all sounds good, but in reality, what happened was I built the main 14 tab report and built the agency-level one off of it before the main report had been finalized. So there have been LOTS of changes to the main report that have not been reflected in the agency-level report. And it's going to remain that way until we're really really done with the main report and it's been finalized and voted on in the Balance of State CoC meeting! I plan to blog more about some of the details of this report, but this should give an overview of how I'm using ART to create it and organize the different needs of the users and board members.

item.title: Reporting on Return to Homelessness (Recurrence)
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
Like many others, we struggle with the idea of defining "recidivism", or the preferred term, "recurrence". HUD won't do it, and no one that I've heard has come out and said, "I GOT IT- this is the definition." It is impossible to code a great report on this without the answers to some of the questions that come out of these "definition" discussions. These discussions often get mired in questions like "what is an episode?" How long does a person need to be out of the system before we consider their return a recurrence? One day? One week? Further, what is the goal of looking at recurrence? Do we count entering into a permanent housing program after a shelter stay as recurrence or is it strictly only returning to shelters and transitional housing? How do we account for shelters with restrictive return policies? If clients are homeless, but aren't showing in recurrence data because they exceeded some locally-imposed quota and so are not allowed to re-enter, is it fair to compare recurrence data for that kind of shelter to recurrence data of shelters that are actively placing people into permanent housing? And on and on!!!
So, when, in our Advanced ART training last month, they covered a very easy way of showing recurrence, it sort of enticed me to play around with that and see where it could get us. <!--more--> The basic design of the report is this:
Built on the Entry Exit universe, there are two queries. Both pull in basic information like Provider, Client ID, Entry Exit ID, Entry and Exit dates. The first tab is called Period 1 (the date range for this can be any set of dates). It uses Provider, Period 1 Start, and Period 1 End Plus One Day prompts, pulling in Stayers and Leavers. Nothing mysterious about this query.
The second query is very similar, except for Client ID, you pull in Client ID from the Year 1 tab by using "results from another query". The prompts are the same as the first query, but you make it read Period 2 Start and Period 2 End Plus One Day. You can either include the Provider prompt in the second query, as was done in the training class, or you can take it out to see all the Entry Exits a client had during the second period, regardless of which provider it was.
When you run it, you make Period 1, say 1/1/2012 to 1/1/2013, and Period 2, 1/1/2013 to now. Choose whichever provider you'd like to know their recurrence rate, and that should be it for the prompts.
When it loads, you should get two tabs, one that shows all the clients from 2012 for the chosen provider, and the second one that shows any clients that were served by that provider in 2012 who also had another Entry Exit in 2013. If you took the provider prompt out of the second query, then you will see all stays any of those clients had, even if they were in permanent housing, rapid rehousing, or whatever.
I haven't really played with this report further, but when I do, I will be pulling in the Provider Type Code so that I can show how many of the clients that recurred were actually returning to homelessness, since that is typically the purpose for pulling recurrence data.
We ran this report on multiple shelters in our CoC and the percentages of returns to homelessness varied widely, but in sort of expected ways, based on what we know of the shelters we picked.
SOME PROBLEMS with this report:
1. It doesn't let you account for any length of time NOT homeless in order to call it a true return to homelessness, instead of really more of the same episode. So, a client could have exited in late December and re-entered somewhere on January 1st, and that client would show as having recurred, even though *some* might call that just more of the same episode of homelessness, depending on how recurrence was defined.
2. It misses instances of recurrence where a client may have been homeless in February 2012, and then again in November 2012, since both of those stays would have been accounted for in the first tab. Granted, you can adjust your dates to say, 6 months at a time, or a quarter at time, or you could even make the first time period a month, and then look at the next two years. Really it all depends on how you run the report.
When you are wanting to study recurrence for the first time in your CoC, these problems can be acknowledged and adjusted for in the expectations set by the CoC. We are not fully decided on how to move forward on recurrence, but this very simple report could make its way into our performance measurements as a very rudimentary look at recurrence.
How are you measuring recurrence?

item.title: Policies and Procedures and Data Quality Standards
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
This does not sound exciting at all, but I think about the most exciting thing that has happened at my work lately is our CoC board voted in an updated Policies and Procedures document and a brand new Data Quality Standards document. As of November 1st, it will be IN EFFECT! <!--more--> It is exciting to me partially because this was a project I helped with for almost a year. Some weeks it went untouched; other weeks, it was all I could think about, but in all, it was really a year's worth of work to get both of those documents ready.
But the main reason it's exciting is it is a sign of a functioning CoC. Not only to be able to come up with logical policies and coherent procedures and get them passed by the CoC board, but also to put into place a process, a set of standards that everyone is held to. When information only comes in emails and presentations, documents, and helpdesk tickets, things are very much left up to individuals fielding questions and susceptible to misunderstandings and misinformation. Publishing documents for data quality standards and HMIS policies brings in an accountability to the agencies in the CoC that was missing before.
Granted, most CoCs already have documents like this, and this should really not be much of a big deal, but in our case, these documents being put into effect after years of having a very out of date Policies and Procedures document is a huge step forward for our CoC! YAY US!

item.title: Why to Use a Provider Assessment
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: Being a Balance of State implementation, it is very difficult to get a handle on which providers are doing what, are funded by whom, etc. Prior to learning about Provider assessments, I never really saw a way of keeping all that straight. The first time I ever heard of Provider assessments, I was at a Bowman conference attending a session presented by an HMIS admin from Maine who was presenting on an ART report he had built. It came up because someone had asked him how he'd been able to separate providers based on an object that is not tracked anywhere in the Provider Admin. He said he'd added the question to his Provider Assessment and showed it to us. I was FLOORED. I did not even wait to get back to the office to create a provider assessment for our implementation. Here are some of the things we track with our provider assessment: Homeless Planning Region - our Balance of State is divided up into 18 regions for planning purposes. Each provider belongs to a region, and this is where we record each provider's region. This prevents me having to use the County field in the Address data objects to divide the providers into their regions. Homeless Dedicated? - some of the providers entering data into our HMIS are not homeless dedicated, and this is important as to whether or not we want them showing on our Housing Inventory Chart (HIC). APR Year Start (and End) - these dates are really only there for the month and day so that we can know when the provider's fiscal year is. This helps us know when to send reminders about APRs that are almost due. Notes - sometimes there are just things to know about a particular provider. This is where we put that. CoC Funded? - for some reports, we only want the CoC-funded providers to show. While there are definitely more questions that could be added, we definitely do not take adding another question to it lightly, because we generally have to go through 400 records to answer them all if the data is going to be of any use. There are some fields (like CoC Funded?) that are only answered if they are NOT CoC funded. I just have to code my reports to look for No's and exclude those instead of reporting on all the Yes's. This saves us a lot of data entry but still gets the job done. The way to set up a provider assessment is exactly like setting up any assessment, but you have to make the Type "Provider Record". Everything from there on is the same as setting up a Client Assessment. Once you are done setting up the provider and assigning it to the providers you want to have it, you have to go into each provider, go to the Assessments tab, assign the assessment, then go to the Assessment Display Settings, and go to the very bottom where it will show the Provider Assessment Display and there is where you pick your new assessment and tell it to show in the Provider Admin for that provider. Once you have it all done, you should be able to pull up the provider in Provider Admin and see the Provider Assessment tab. I highly recommend using the Provider assessment to help with custom reporting! What are some questions you have added (or are going to add) to your provider assessment?

item.title: Doing your Housing Inventory Chart (HIC) from HMIS
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: Last year was our first year doing our Housing Inventory Chart mostly from HMIS. I say mostly because not all agencies on the HIC are entering data into HMIS, so those obviously didn't come out of HMIS. This year, the plan is to do our HIC completely out of HMIS. We are currently collecting all the extraneous provider data that the HMIS APR looks at in regards to Provider Data Quality, then once we have that, we will be entering that into our system. Once that is done, we will use the Bowman-created HIC (again). There's a really annoying problem with it though: it returns two rows for every provider that has two types of beds. ERGH! I solved that by using formulas in all the affected columns, depending on which one you're looking at. This example is for Target Population A, but the same formula applies to the other text based columns like McKinney Vento, etc.: =If(Count([Target Pop A];Distinct)>1; Min([Target Pop A])+ " & " + Max([Target Pop A]); [Target Pop A]) This basically says if there is more than one bed record for one provider, and those records are set to different values for the field "Target Population A", then print the first one (alphabetically), then an ampersand surrounded by spaces, then print the last one (alphabetically). And if there's not more than one bed record for the provider, then just print the value. This way if there are two types represented, they will both show in the same row, separated by the "and" sign. Just a note: I wrote this formula before I realized that "distinct" was assumed, so that is probably not necessary in the formula. But it does work, so I'm leaving it in. Before I could use this, I had to make sure there were no legitimate instances where there could be three separate types of something for a single provider and there was not. The reason this formula would not work if this were a real situation, is the formula looks for the Min and Max, or the first and last, never the middle. It could theoretically be a problem down the road, but right now I cannot think of a good reason that one provider would have three separate bed records. Once I had this formula in each cell (adjusted for which column I was looking at), I then had to worry about the columns with the bed counts. Since these are numeric and not text based, the formula uses Sum: =Sum([Bed and Unit Inventory Bed Inventory] Where( [Bed and Unit Inventory Availability]="Year-Round" And [Bed and Unit Inventory Household Type]="Households without children") In([Data].[Provider])) So for a provider with 2 family beds and 4 individual beds, that provider would, without these formulas, show as two rows, one row showing the 2 family beds and 0 for the individual beds, and the other row showing 0 for the family beds and 4 for the individual beds. This formula adds the 4 and the 0 and puts it all in one cell instead of letting it be split out like that. I used a variation of this formula across all the columns like this. Once these formulas were in place, the splitting out of providers into two rows stopped and we could use the data straight out of HMIS. Hope this helps! Leave a comment if you have other suggestions or better ways!!

item.title: How to slice strings in Business Objects
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: The Quarterly Performance Report (QPR) I've been working on for months now is FINALLY to the stages of being edited for tiny things like the exact verbiage in the header, how it looks, and sorting out the alerters, etc. On each of the reports, there is a formula designed to state the goal of the specified performance measurement, based on the Program Type Code the report was run on. So depending on the answer to the Program Type Code prompt, the verbiage in that cell changes to match the goals for that program type using nested If statements. In each one of them, I had the exact "Program Type Code" showing as part of the sentence. So it would read like: "Goal: 83% of Transitional housing (HUD) participants will exit to permanent housing." That's weird because "Transitional housing (HUD)" is not a natural way of writing, and it is confusing to some who are not funded by HUD but who are going to be held to the standards in this report. The problem is that is the exact wording (and weird capitalization) for that particular program type code answer and it cannot be changed otherwise everything will break! At first I was at a loss on this one because there is no function in Business Objects like there is in Python that just lets you lop off characters like this. Trim() only lops off spaces. So my office mate found this blog: https://bobjblog.wordpress.com/2013/06/06/how-to-remove-a-specified-number-of-characters-from-a-string/ and sent it my way. It reminded me you can combine functions to do things that are lacking in the functions list. Since the aim in the article I linked to was similar, it was just a matter of time to figure out to use the Left() and Pos() functions together, and I added the WordCap function to it for my own purposes. WordCap( Left( UserResponse(Program Type Code:); Pos(UserResponse(Program Type Code:); ( ) ) ) The Pos() function returns the position value of the string " (" since that is where we want to slice. The Left() function says to return everything to the left of that " (". And finally, the WordCap () function just forces the string into title case. So "Transitional housing (HUD)" turns into "Transitional Housing " and now my goal looks like: "Goal: 83% of Transitional Housing participants will exit to permanent housing." Now all my goals read like plain English!

item.title: Length of Time to Data Entry
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: If you are new to ART (Business Objects) reporting (or even if you're not) and would like a very simple ART report to design from scratch, this is a good one. For our CoC, we have a policy that HMIS users have 5 days to enter a household into HMIS from the day they entered the program. We have had this policy for ages, but until last year when I designed this report, the grant managers had no way of verifying this was happening except to spot check the paper file and check in HMIS for the "Date Added" date. So I created a report called "Desk Time" that the grant managers use regularly to get an idea how long client files are sitting on case managers' desks or how long it's taking to get transferred from the intake person to the data entry person before going into HMIS. It is only one query, based on the Entry Exit universe. The result objects included are: Provider ID, Client ID, Entry Date, and Date Added. In the query filter, I have Client Inactive and Entry Exit Inactive set to No, a Provider prompt set to In List so users can select multiple Providers, and then I have it pulling in all Entry Exits that began in the last year from the date the report is being run. So I pulled in the Entry Date, set it to Greater Than or Equal To, then I used the object in the Date Objects folder called "Right Now - 1 year ago". Since this report was only going to be used for one thing, I didn't feel it was necessary to force the grant managers to choose a date range, and they said they just wanted to see a year of data, so this was good for us. You may choose to make this a prompt, however. Once the report is run, there are two tabs: one that shows the list of providers in one column and the average Desk Time in the other. I also have an average for the group of providers being run in case they want to see that. The other tab is the Detail tab and has a section break on the Provider ID, then a block with the following columns: Client ID, Entry Date, Date Added, and Desk Time. In the Desk Time column, I have it referring to a variable I created named "Days". The formula is: =DaysBetween([Entry Exit Entry Date];[Entry Exit Date Added]) If you click the Desk Time column and then click the arrow on the Sum button in the toolbar and click Average, it will show the average for each Provider section. This provides the agency with the detail of each client being counted so that they know how the average is being derived. When you are done, you will want to be sure the averages on the Detail tab match the average listed on the Summary tab. You may consider adding a Median as well, if your users are interested in knowing this measure. This report runs very quickly and is usually only about two pages long, depending on the size of the project(s) you pull into the report. I don't know about your CoC, but most of the Desk Time averages for ours are way higher than 5 days. Sometimes it is due to one crazy outlier, other times you can tell that the case manager waits til they have a block of time free and enter everything from the prior month or two all on one day. This is what we are trying to avoid. One gaping hole in this whole idea is that the policy that applies to time to enter a household into a program also applies to how long users have to EXIT households. However, there is no way that I know of to tell which day a user actually entered the Exit Data without going in to the audit data which I do not want to do. The reason this is a problem is Bed Utilization and the AHAR. When users forget to exit their clients, they have insanely high client counts compared to their bed counts. So if you have any ideas on how to include that piece, add a comment! Happy reporting!

item.title: Is this Provider Still Entering Data???
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: Last year, we did a giant audit of all 400 of our providers, one by one, asking grant managers and others who had more intimate knowledge of the individual projects if each one was still in business, because there were so many that were no longer in use that we couldn't tell what was what. We had some turnover in our department and a LOT of knowledge had left the building. It was an emergency effort to try and understand which providers were in our HMIS. We wanted to get to the point where we could say for sure that each provider in the HMIS was set up correctly. As part of that effort, I created a report called "Most Recent EE Activity by Provider". It was really helpful to know when the last time any Entry Exit was updated for a program stay in that provider. It is only one query, and in the Entry Exit universe. The result objects are Provider ID, Entry Date, Exit Date, EE Date Updated, and Entry Exit ID. The query filters are just filtering out the EE Inactive and Client Inactives. When I run the report, the tab simply shows a block with the following columns: Provider ID, Most Recent Entry Date, Most Recent Exit Date, and Most Recent Date This Entry Exit Was Updated. In each of the last three columns, I just have the Max() function with one of the date fields. =Max([Entry Exit Entry Date]) =Max([Entry Exit Exit Date]) =Max([Entry Exit Last Updated]) This way, for each provider, I could see the most recent Entry Date, the most recent Exit Date, and when the last time any Entry Exit data was last updated. This really helped along the conversation at times when people were in doubt about whether or not a provider was entering data. This is another very simple report, and one that may show providers who may need to be removed from your lists of active providers. It actually takes longer to run this report because there is no date range and so it is pulling in ALL the active Entry Exit Dates ever into the report. If you have ideas as to how to design this better, please share in the comments!

item.title: Law Enforcement and the HMIS
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: In [], the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) commissioned that homeless service providers begin collecting client data in a coordinated way, and thus the Homeless Management Information System (HMIS) was born, along with all its governing documents and rules regarding privacy, what data gets collected, how often, reporting requirements, and more recently, performance measures. It has been an unprecedented success. In the beginnings, it gave us our first unduplicated homeless counts. More recently, it is being used for serious data analysis including mapping the geography of homelessness, tracking performance measures to meet the overarching goal of ending homelessness, and prioritizing housing for those most in need, just to name a few. When HMIS was first introduced, there was much concern about the privacy and security of client data. HUD created legislation around how client data should be handled (after a good deal of pushback[] from providers and privacy advocates.) [] The concern is that people in housing crises are in vulnerable situations, and keeping all their data in one place can put them at risk of their information being compromised, thus further marginalizing them. HUD requires that each client acknowledge that their data is being entered, and that they understand who then would ever have access to it, and that those agreements be renewed every year the client is in the program. The federal register states that the only people who should have access to client data are those using the data to provide services. [] Clients who do not feel comfortable sharing their information with providers or having it entered into HMIS in a way that identifies them can opt to have their data entered anonymously, however, given that you need some way of de-duplicating clients, the more clients that opt for anonymity, the less useful HMIS data becomes. In our CoC, we allow anonymous data entry and it does not amount to enough of a problem to really even worry about. What many case managers have to convince wary clients of is that the data is only for the purpose of providing services to the clients and it is not accessed by any law enforcement agency or places of employment or landlords or otherwise available to people who have or may have power over the client at some time. This is important because landlords have been known to refuse to rent to clients who "come from shelter" or who have had domestic violence or even just based on the ages of a family's kid(s).Employers have also been known to discriminate in their hiring practices against people who are or even have been homeless, and police have a long awful history of abuse toward homeless folks. [] So the privacy requirements for HMIS were written to be clear about who should have access to HMIS data, but alas, they were not actually clear. What if police officers say they will "provide services" to people who are homeless? Does that now mean that police could convince HMIS Leads to grant them access? Unfortunately, it does. But HMIS Leads certainly have the authority to prevent that kind of intrusion based on the power dynamic described above between police and people who are homeless. Even police programs like H.O.T. (Homeless Outreach Team), which has helped many people find shelter or housing, have no business in HMIS. They are not actually providing services so much as referring people to where they can get help, which is actually part of their job anyway. Protect and Serve. Bringing a person freezing under a bridge to a warming shelter would not require access to HMIS. All it would require is a list of local agencies and an understanding of the services they offer, plus an address in case the client needs a ride. Police doing outreach to people who are homeless are actually doing police work, not homeless services. Opening up homeless clients' personally identifying information to police officers is a very bad idea. As I've explained thus far, there really is no reason to do it. I intend to also explain why it should NOT be done. Successful homeless services agencies work diligently to gain the trust of their clients. Not to be crass, but part of the capital gained from that trust is, quite honestly, the data. Up til now, that data has been used solely to help these agencies plan and coordinate services better, both regionally, at the state level, and nationally. It has driven sorely needed changes to the homeless services sector's understanding of where service agencies are helping and where they're exacerbating the problem. That trust is hard-earned and well used, for the most part. So let's talk a bit more about the trust relationship between homeless populations and police, shall we?http://homelesshub.ca/sites/default/files/Trust_and_Interactions_with_Police_and_Paramedics%28JUH%29.pdfhttps://www.researchgate.net/publication/260087219_Interactions_with_the_Police_Experiences_of_the_Homeless_in_Mental_Health_Crisishttp://aclunv.org/kyr/homeless Given this tenuous and important relationship between successful homeless organizations and their clients, and the experiences thathomeless populations have had to endure with the police, it is easy to imagine that homeless clients who understand that the police will have access to their data, might refuse to allow their data to be shared or refuse to give their data at all, or outright refuse shelter based on the knowledge that homeless services agencies align themselves with the police and not with humanitarian aid, temporary housing, referrals, and safety. Another serious problem is that homeless services data is not meant to aid the police in the surveillance of homeless residents of a community. These clients have a right to privacy. HMIS is meant to aid agencies in serving them with housing, aid, referrals, and safety. Opening up HMIS data to policeviolates their 4th Amendment rights(prohibiting unreasonable search and seizure). A search in the HMIS database could indeed be quite the gold mine of information. It would not only give personally identifying information, but dates and times and places where the person/household stayed, their homeless history, disabilities, income, benefits, veteran status, who they were with on various nights in various locations, their destination upon exit, where they came from prior to entry, etc. Some CoCs collect way more information that is required, such as rental history, education levels, pregnancy status, and other information, so all this would be available as well, if it was set up that way.

item.title: 10 Ways R Could Help Your HMIS Data Analysis Workflow
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
Regardless of what visualization tool you decide to use, whether that's Power BI, Tableau, R Shiny, or whatever else, R is a really great way to organize your data into whatever shapes you are needing for your visualizations. It can be used as a way of staging your data sets in a reproducible, sharable, and version-controlled way.

10. Free use of the language (No subscriptions)

R is free and open source, and costs nothing. We do not pay anything for the use of R or R Studio. There is no subscription fee and there never will be. See the GNU licensing here: https://www.gnu.org/licenses/old-licenses/gpl-2.0.en.html

9. Constant updates and excellent support (No support contracts)

R is gaining popularity inside and outside of its science and academic roots and is thus gaining a lot of new developers interested in creating new packages and improving on old ones. An example of this is a group of packages designed to work well together called the Tidyverse. When I have had issues, I found quick and friendly responses at no cost.

8. Giant friendly community

The R community really is one of the best I've experienced. There are so many resources that I can be choosy about the best way for me to interact. There are newsletters, community forums, Slack channels, R Ladies meetups, a podcast, a huge presence on GitHub, Rainbow R, blogs, and the #rstats hashtag on Twitter. I stick to Slack, Twitter, and R Ladies meetups, but really there is something for everyone.

I could name many things I have gained from being involved with the R community, but the most amazing and helpful one was from a Slack channel. I posted asking for help getting started with a Shiny app for our users and an OSU student messaged me. He came to mentor me every Friday, pushing me through logjams so I could think about other things and not get stuck. Really he made such a difference in everything.

7. Lots of free and excellent training resources

One of the largest obstacles I hear from people who are interested in using R is the learning curve. The idea of going from the familiar Excel or other drag and drop type of data tool to the more linear "code" format is sometimes a really big barrier. I would argue you're already coding in those other systems. Most likely, with the complex type of data we are using, you are not simply sorting and formatting your HMIS data.

Once you come around to this, or even before(!), you can find many excellent and free training resources. I've said this before, but my favorite two (among many that I've never even tried) are:

  1. R for Data Science
  2. Swirl: learn R, in R

6. Easier Troubleshooting

As mentioned above, writing code as opposed to mousing around in a well-known software may or may not be something you're real excited about, but it has its advantages!

One advantage is it is more reproducible. Someone else (including future-you) looking at your work will much more easily see what was done to the raw data to get it to its final state. Well-written code has a beginning, a middle, and an end. A complex Excel workbook can look very simple but have hidden columns, tabs, formulas, locked cells, vlookups and all the goods, and it can be right (or not), but if an outsider can't look at how it was created, they can't really know what is happening when the user interacts with it and it is very difficult to troubleshoot or document your steps.

When you're writing code, since you can run parts and pieces of it, it is easy to tell where things go wrong. "What's taking this so long?" is easily found. "At what point am I getting duplicate rows?" Also easily solved if you check your results step by step.

You can comment your code with the reasoning behind certain coding decisions you made so that others will understand (or you will remember) what your goals were when you created the analysis.

5. Ability to Code Something Once and Use the Same Code Everywhere

In our world, I have found there are some functions we need that simply don't exist in the wild because it's so specific to our line of work. For instance, I have created several functions that I use constantly that I could make into a package (but I have not). Some examples are:

  1. served_between- pulls all clients who entered prior to the Report End Date and who either never exited or exited after the Report Start Date.
  2. stayed_between- pulls all clients who -EITHER- entered an ES, TH, or SH project - OR- had a valid Move-In Date into a RRH or PSH project, prior to the Report End Date and who either never exited or exited after the Report Start Date.
  3. operating_between- pulls all projects that were operating between the Report Start and Report End Dates.
  4. chronic_self, chronic_hh, chronic_nearly (these ones are in the works!)

I use these and other functions I created throughout all my scripts, which prevents me from having to rewrite that code over and over again, decreasing errors and time spent. If any of these change, I only have to change it once and it affects all reporting based on it.

4. Ability to Create an R Package of Your Own

The functions I mentioned above could be compiled into an R package. Anyone could install that package and have those functions for their own work, contribute to it, offer up improvements, etc.

R has so many possibilities for what we are all doing. I feel like we are generally all trying to do similar work and it would be super cool to build stuff together using free and open source software.

3. Ability to Publish Analyses Behind a Login at a Reasonable Cost (R Shiny and shinyapps.io!)

An important difference I noticed when considering whether I should use R for data shaping + something else like Qlik Sense Cloud or Tableau for data visualization is that all the other solutions charged a LOT of money if you wanted to create something and have it behind a login for users.

With shinyapps.io, I have been able to keep to my usual way of doing things in ART: create an analysis for publication that is aggregate data only, where the granularity only goes to the project level, and then also create a second report for the end user so they can check each aggregation down to the client-level granularity. The aggregate reporting is made public, but never client-level data. Also, we would also never publish a dashboard or any kind of data visualization publicly if our users were not able to easily check these numbers at the client level. Here's why:

1. Giving them this ability improves data quality. It is a great way to be sure your users understand the importance of the data they are entering

2. It invites our users to question the way we are calculating things and has in the past brought out really good questions that caused us to make changes to the reporting

3. User questions have sometimes shone a light on actual coding errors on my part

You wind up with better data quality, better informed users, and better code. Even better, shinyapps.io is very easy, well-designed, and well-supported by R Studio. (It costs us $99/month.)

2. Reproducibility

The combination of being able to look at code and tell what happened to the raw data from start to finish and being able to make it available for others to verify or re-use is the reason I get so excited about the possibilities for R in the homeless services data community.

It is also important to me for reasons of integrity. Homelessness is becoming more and more of an issue that people not in our circles think about. As such, our data presentation can have significant power to help (or harm) those we aim to serve. Our workflows give us a way to hold a space for integrity in this era of corruption and journalistic dishonesty.

1. Version Control and Control Over Your Code

A long time ago, I did a sweet little blog post here about Version Control in ART and it's great because it recognizes the importance of version control and then goes on to instruct you on how to manually version-control your ART reports with no help from ART itself.

I have also blogged a number of times about how version control in R Studio coordinates easily with GitHub or other git repository systems. The advantage (besides the ease of use) is you can work with others on the same project and not overwrite anyone's code without their explicit permission. It offers a great avenue for communication and collaboration.

I mostly work alone, but I constantly push and pull code to and from my laptop to my work computer.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Could another person (including future-you) get the same exact results you did? Could you easily explain the numbers behind your visualizations if questioned?

item.title: UPDATED: Providers: To Delete or Not To Delete.. (Hint: Not)
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever deleted a provider in ServicePoint? What was your favorite repercussion?
  1. Still seeing it in lists of providers in ART
  2. Not being able to access the provider admin for the provider, which of course you wouldn't want or need to do if it wasn't still showing up in ART, (please see update at the bottom!) or
  3. In ART, not having a way to filter on whether a provider has been deleted in ServicePoint or not
  4. Realizing deleting the provider does not remove its answers to provider admin questions like "CoC Code" from the list of possible answers to choose from? For example, say years ago, someone typed in Oh-507 instead of OH-507. Then forever and always, you will have two CoC Codes to choose from in the CoC Code prompt list: Oh-507 and OH-507. And even though it doesn't really affect anything, it's really annoying that you cannot fix it due to the fact that you cannot access the provider admin for that deleted provider. (again, see update at the bottom!)
I do get that these "repercussions" are this way so that you can still report on deleted providers, but I think it makes more sense for admins to only delete providers when you can say for sure you will not need to report on those providers anymore. There has to be a point at which admins simply take responsibility just like we do by merging clients, adjusting visibility settings, and all the rest of it. The data standards indicate that all data over 7 years old should be archived, so why the need to keep every last provider, even ones that have closed ten or more years ago? Short of that solution, it would also work if you could control through the interface whether you are deleting a provider and all its provider data (but not the client data) forever or simply removing it from the list in ServicePoint, from any reporting groups, etc. As it is, you delete the provider thinking you actually deleted it from ServicePoint and from ART reporting, but in reality, you have only prevented yourself from having control over the provider's admin settings, thus forever locking yourself in to whatever settings existed when you deleted it. So for now, we've decided not to delete any providers. Then does one deal with those providers that do not exist any more and haven't for years? How do you get them to stop junking up your lists in ART and how can you easily distinguish the active providers from the inactive? We have started to call what we do "soft deleting" or "parking" a provider. Here's our process for that: Once we have been notified there's a provider no longer in business, we take the following steps:
  1. Go to Provider Admin, pull up the provider, and add "zz" to the beginning of the provider name. This pushes it to the end of the list you see in ART provider lists so that they aren't junking up everything.
  2. Look at which assessments are assigned to the provider, go to Assessment Admin, and remove the provider(s) from the list of providers with each assessment. This ensures that users cannot enter assessment data into that provider anymore. It does *not* prevent users from adding Entry Exits or Service Transactions, however.
  3. Go to the Provider Access tab to check to see which users have access to this provider, then go to each user and remove their access.
  4. Uncheck the "Operational" checkbox and the "Uses ServicePoint" checkbox. Unchecking the "Operational" checkbox removes it from ResourcePoint and the possibility of referrals being assigned to it. Unchecking the "Uses ServicePoint" checkbox does not really affect much except how the provider looks in the list of providers in Provider Admin, but if you have built custom reports based on the field (which we have), it is important to maintain this field.
  5. Go to the HUD Standards tab and add end dates to the bed count data, indicating the last date they were open. Or if you don't know or it's so old it doesn't matter, just delete the bed records altogether.
  6. Maybe: delete the CoC Code. I say "maybe" because if the project being parked still hasn't fulfilled its reporting requirements, and your reports pull providers based on the CoC Code field, then you should leave the CoC Code populated until you are done reporting on that agency. (If you use that field in your reporting.)
Truthfully, this is a process in flux, and will likely change as we learn more about what we are doing, and what is connected to what. I'm curious to know how others do it or what things we are doing that are maybe unnecessary or if there's anything we're leaving out. Also, when we noticed all the previously deleted providers showing in ART reports and lists, we asked if Bowman would please really delete them and they did actually do that for us. Things have improved greatly since then now that we are not seeing all those old providers. How do you manage your inactive providers? UPDATE: Since this posting, I have learned through Sarah G at Bowman that there is actually a way for us admins to access and edit deleted providers' admin pages! I actually did it today and solved a lot of problems we have been having. Are you ready?
  1. Go to Provider Admin and find any provider to click on, it doesn't matter which one.
  2. Select the numbers at the end of the URL in your browser. Those numbers are the provider ID.
  3. Type in the Provider ID of the deleted provider you would like to administer.
  4. Make whatever changes you want and Save.
This is obviously more of a hack than a feature, but it works, and it beats the alternatives. The reason this has been valuable to us is a lot of those deleted providers had CoC Codes saved to them, and so they were getting pulled into our NOFA and any other report because we tend to use CoC Code as a prompt in a lot of our reports, and since those deleted providers had CoC Codes, they were being pulled in, regardless of their having been deleted. The other way it helped was that I was able to add zz to the front of the name field so that these deleted providers did not show blended in with other active providers. So- thanks Sarah! To conclude, maybe if deleting providers works differently one day, we will start cleaning up those soft-deleted providers. But for now, we are going to stick to soft-deleting because there are not currently any advantages to deleting them.

item.title: Accommodating Green Users
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded:
One of the more challenging parts of my job is working with users who show up to a new user training having never used a computer. Or who have, but they just do not feel comfortable with computers. It's difficult enough being a case manager without also having to learn basic computer skills plus entering data about humans (which is complex by nature) into ServicePoint, then reporting on that data. This situation brings up many questions and I have noticed that various HMIS implementations address them in different ways. In an implementation of 80 counties, we have to really think out our strategy as far as how much time we can spend doing things for the users that they can do for themselves. One of my strategies is to focus on empowering users to run their own reports and think about the system, as much as possible, in terms of generalities. For some, this strategy does not work. They need to hear micro steps verbally and sometimes even then it is a struggle. So you have to do as much hand holding as is necessary but no more. It's a really tricky line to walk, and I think I have much to learn about where that line is. Some of the things I do to help struggling users use the system successfully are:
  • Use Provider Admin to steer them in the right direction. Set up all your providers in a similar manner. Use the Summary Tab and arrange the dashlets in the order of the workflow. Every provider is set up the same so that users with more than one provider feel at home regardless of which provider they're entering data for.
  • Use Provider Admin to steer them AWAY from the WRONG direction. When we have to attach users to a parent provider, some of these users will consistently forget to click Enter Data As (EDA). It is drilled again and again in the New User Training, but sometimes it just does not sink in. For these cases, we use Provider Admin settings to remind them that they should not be entering data into that parent provider. One of the actions we took to prevent this is we added an assessment called "PLEASE CLICK ENTER DATA AS!". And in it, we put a Header named something similar, and then no questions at all. We attached this to the worst offenders' parent providers from Assessment Admin. In Provider Admin, we go to Modules, then ClientPoint, check the Attach Assessment to Summary Tab box (we normally have it off), and uncheck all the Dashlets. Then in the Assessments tab, we attach that new assessment named Please Click Enter Data As to the Summary Tab. This makes that assessment with the message we want show up on all client records pulled up as that parent provider. We also removed all the other assessments, though doing this prevents users at that level from looking at client data in the parent provider, but to me it is less important that they can view client data at the parent provider level than it is that they do not enter data at that level. This setup trick is not airtight, because users can still save an Entry Exit to that parent provider if they really try, but it has cut back on the amount of data entered into parent providers.
  • Go easy on drastic changes. Too much of a change to workflow at once can put off the users who are struggling.
  • Set up a Knowledge Base. We use HelpSpot, but short of purchasing a helpdesk system, you could simply maintain a page on your company's website to link to some guidance documents that describe how to do various things. Use lots of screenshots!!!
  • Stay in contact with your users. Send out helpful, relevant, and regular emails.
  • Make sure that someone at every agency has an ART license. Empower your users to run their own reports. This is really important because the people entering the data need access to it, not just to report to HUD, or so that you don't have to do it (though that is important too), but because when users see their data in aggregate, it does something to them. Things fall into place, or they see how things do not fall into place because of data quality or because of various other things that we, in our black shiny building (we are in a black shiny building), would not understand.
  • Realize that sometimes you will have to sit on the phone with or visit in person those who are really struggling.
  • Get rid of the need to backdate if possible. Backdating is so 2010!! Our implementation does not use ShelterPoint (yet) or CallPoint or many of the other modules more urban implementations use, so it is possible that backdating has to stay for some implementations. But if you only make your assessments available in the Entry Exit Assessment Display area of the Assessments tab in Provider Admin, users will not ever need to backdate, especially if you have implemented Interims and Followups. Why? Because entering assessment data in the Entry Exit window automatically backdates your assessment data to match the Entry Date (or Exit Date whichever you're in). Therefore we do not show assessments anywhere except in the Entry Exits. Not the Client Profile, and not the Client Summary. The one place you cannot control whether users access the assessments or not is the Assessments tab in the Client record, but we just try to be very clear in the training that they should not edit data in the Assessments tab, only view it. I think that training users to backdate where it isn't necessary ratchets up the complexity of the task, and intimidates users.
  • Create custom reports for your users and only include the data they need to see. More data is not always better. You know the needs of your users better than Bowman could. Their reports are great in that they give lots of data, but a report with 25 columns on one page is too much for users to find useful. At the very least, you can rename column headings and slide some of the more irrelevant columns (like Group ID or Entry Exit ID) closed so that they do not show (do not remove them, however, because the logic will change). Another way to help break down the reports into something more readable is to duplicate a tab (or "report" in ART-speak) you would like the users to see and pre-set some Input Controls so that the users won't need to. Rename the tab appropriately.
Anyway, hopefully these things can help with leveling off some of the anxiety your users may have in regards to entering data into ServicePoint. Leave a comment to add to this or make suggestions about anything I've said here! Hope to hear other ways of making life easier for the greenest of our users!

item.title: UPDATE: Calculating Chronic Homelessness Priority based on Turnover
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: UPDATE: Since this blog post was published, HUD has released new guidance on how to calculate this. However, I feel like this way of doing it makes a lot of sense and could be useful for folks who just want to know this kind of information for internal processes. So, use it if it suits you, but don't use it on the NOFA! :) ____________________________________________________________________________ According to the HUD CoC NOFA 2013-2014, HUD wants to know the percentage of beds not dedicated to serving chronic clients that are being used to serve chronic clients, but they don't explain exactly how to calculate that. How I calculated this: First, I checked the Housing Inventory Chart and figured out that 20% of our PSH beds are dedicated to chronic. Then, I built an ART report on the EE universe. Two queries: All Exiting: Pulls clients who exited during the year. This is to get the amount of turnover. I pulled in Client ID, EE ID, Entry Date, and Exit Date. I filtered out inactives, and added a filter for Exit Date using the "between" function. I put the beginning of the year to the end of the year for that filter, then I also filtered on Program Type Code since this is only for Permanent Supportive Housing. This will show all EXITS during the year for all PSH projects, thus giving us the number of times a bed/voucher was "turned over". Chronic Entering: Pulls all chronic clients who entered a PSH project during the year. I basically made a duplicate of the above query and added in "Is Client Chronically Homeless?". The other important difference is instead of filtering on the Exit Date, I filtered on the Entry Date because I want to see how many chronic clients entered PSH during the year. The idea with pulling these two pieces is to compare how many chronic clients entered PSH to the number of beds that turned over during the year. (This assumes that all beds that were vacated were actually turned over, but I cannot think of a clean way to avoid this.) When I ran it, I kept the data blocks that defaulted for kicks, but also created a blank cell with the following formula in it: =(Count([Chronic Entering].[Entry Exit Client Id]) Where ([Is Client Chronically Homeless?(932)]="Yes"))/Count([All Exiting].[Entry Exit Client Id])-0.2 Format it as a percentage. After comparing how many beds became available during the year to how many were given to chronically homeless clients, we then subtract the percentage of beds that were dedicated to chronically homeless persons because we are assuming that all the chronic clients were put in chronic beds.We are left with the percentage of chronic clients served in beds not dedicated to chronically homeless persons. I hope this helps someone! If I'm missing something, please leave a comment!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:

item.title: How to Calculate Shelter Nights
item.dc:creator: Genelle
item.content:encoded: We have had many agencies call to ask where to find a calculation of shelter nights. This means that each night a client is served in their program counts as one shelter night. It is measured between two dates, so that the nightly client count served on each night in the date range is added together to give a total number of "shelter nights". It seems like a really straightforward idea that should be really easy to calculate, but the trick is cutting off program stays at either end of the date range. The way I built this report is using one query, on the Entry Exit Universe. Use Client ID, Entry Date, Exit Date, and Provider ID.
